China Unleashes Rapid Drop in New-Home Prices With Relaxed Curbs

At least 10 cities relaxed, removed new home price guidance
New projects in Beijing, Shenzhen have also slashed price

A price war is spreading across Chinaâ€™s new-home market, as local governments dial back on intervention and developers race to recoup cash.
In Beijing, a sudden 18% price cut in May at a mid-sized residential project on the cityâ€™s outskirts has forced adjacent new developments to follow suit, according to people familiar, who requested not to be named because the matter is private. Near the southern border, the Shenzhen government approved a 29% cut in unit prices for a complex compared with a year ago, according to other people familiar.


After intervening for years, at least 10 city governments have relaxed or scrapped new-home price guidances to let market demand play a bigger role, according to China Index Holdings Ltd. and public statements.


While itâ€™s mostly smaller cities that have announced the moves, the examples in Beijing and Shenzhen show that even bureaucrats in megacities are starting to relax prices on a case-by-case basis.
The move is expected to drive more developers to cut prices as they benchmark against the second-hand market thatâ€™s seen a much steeper decline. That will help remove longstanding market distortions created by government meddling, even if it keeps some buyers on the sidelines as they wait to see how far new-home values will fall.
â€œThis will likely translate into more downside to home prices in most cities,â€ said Kristy Hung, a Bloomberg Intelligence analyst. It â€œwould be detrimental to sentiment as potential buyers wait for prices to bottom before getting into the game.â€
That spells trouble for the incremental improvement in home prices seen in July. The housing ministry in Beijing and Shenzhen didnâ€™t respond to respective queries.
Price Intervention
Other cities that have joined the trend include Zhengzhou, the capital of central Chinaâ€™s Henan province. Home to one of Apple Inc.â€™s largest iPhone manufacturing sites, it ended the use of price guidances for new homes in July, effectively allowing real estate firms to set values based on market demand. Wuhan followed suit the same day.
For years, Chinaâ€™s housing authority tinkered with the price range at which new homes were sold through a â€œpre-sales permit.â€ The approach kept new-home prices in the biggest cities in check since late 2016 following a property frenzy. But when second-hand homes went into freefall, the arrangement kept new-home values abnormally resilient. That in turn made it even harder for companies to sell their inventory.
â€œRestrictions on home price declines have hindered developersâ€™ sales since mid-2021,â€ said Chen Wenjing, a research director at property agency China Index Holdings. â€œEasing or removing such restrictions will allow them to set prices reasonably.â€

In a fundamental shift, existing-home sales overtook that of new ones in China for the first time last year, as buyers hunted for better bargains.
New-home values have declined about 7.2% from June 2021, about half of the 13.6% drop seen in existing-home prices.
China New-Home Prices Have Fallen Less Than That of Used Ones
Local housing authorities controlled new home prices
Source: National Bureau of Statistics of China, Bloomberg
Prices of second-hand homes in Shenzhen, once Chinaâ€™s least affordable city, have plunged 37% from a peak in May 2021, according to Centaline Group. Theyâ€™ve tanked by about 27% in Beijing, Shanghai and Guangzhou from their respective peaks.
The bargains pushed Shenzhenâ€™s existing-home sales in July to the highest by monthly volume in more than four years, according to the cityâ€™s biggest real estate agency Leyoujia. The same month, its new-home sales shrank 11% by units from a month earlier.






Similarly, the slump of nationwide new-home sales deepened in July.
Many of the cash-strapped developers, who have been in default for more than a year, are counting on sales to reassure debt holders and fight off liquidation.
At least 20 Chinese developers have faced wind-up petitions, according to data compiled by Bloomberg. Dexin China Holdings Co. in June became the latest builder to receive a liquidation order from a Hong Kong court, following China Evergrande Group and Jiayuan International Group Ltd.
Developer Liquidity Stress
In addition, about 80 out of the top 200 real estate companies operating in China have been mired in default, according to data compiled by Bloomberg. More could follow as new-home sales havenâ€™t fully recovered, China Real Estate Information Corp warned in note on Aug. 8.

Local governments are piling on the pressure, with the Guangdong provincial government urging developers to raise funds via asset disposal and not â€œlie flat,â€ a popular term referring to lack of effort.
China Home Sales Slump Drags On
Source: China Real Estate Information Corp.
As new-home prices begin to come down in Chinaâ€™s biggest cities, the government may be reaching similar conclusions even though such policies have yet to be officially announced.
In May, Beijingâ€™s Oak Bay by state-backed builder China Resources Land Ltd. cut its asking price for some units to 54,000 yuan per square meter, about 18% lower than when it debuted in September last year, according to people familiar.
Two nearby projects also had prices slashed. CSC Jiuyue Palace cut the prices of some units to 56,000 yuan per square meter. China Blossoms went further, offering selective units as low as 50,000 yuan per square meter, 31% lower than government-guided prices earlier, according to a sales agent.
In southern Shenzhen, â€œalmost every new-home projectâ€ is on discount, according to a July note from Leyoujia.
â€œNew-home prices will be more â€˜reasonableâ€™ once theyâ€™re allowed to fluctuate only based on supply and demand,â€ said Yan Yuejin, vice president of Shanghai E-houseâ€™s research arm. â€œRemoving restrictions on price setting heralds thorough loosening in real estate policies.â€
